name: Eco-Friendly Industry
title: Lowest F-gases Emissions from Industrial Processes
description: In 2023, Zambia recorded the lowest F-gases emissions from industrial processes globally, with a value of just 0.0001 Mt CO2e.

name: Affordable Health Care
title: Minimal Out-of-Pocket Health Care Expenditure
description: In 2015, only 0.01% of Zambia's population spent more than 25% of their household consumption or income on out-of-pocket health care, indicating affordable health services.

name: Vitamin A Champions
title: High Vitamin A Supplementation Coverage
description: In 2022, Zambia achieved a 97% coverage rate for Vitamin A supplementation among children aged 6-59 months, showcasing strong public health initiatives.

name: Education Challenges
title: High Learning Poverty and Reading Proficiency Issues
description: In 2019, 98.5% of Zambian children at the end-of-primary age were below minimum reading proficiency, highlighting significant challenges in the education sector.

name: Youthful Education System
title: Late Start to Lower Secondary Education
description: Zambia's lower secondary school starting age is 14 years as of 2023, which is higher than many countries, potentially delaying educational progression.

name: Balanced Births
title: Balanced Sex Ratio at Birth
description: In 2023, Zambia maintained a balanced sex ratio at birth with 1.011 male births per female birth, indicating gender parity at birth.

name: Education Investment
title: High Expenditure on Primary Education
description: In 2017, Zambia allocated 67.35% of its government education expenditure to primary education, emphasizing the importance of foundational learning.

name: Financial Stability
title: Negative Risk Premium on Lending
description: In 2020, Zambia had a risk premium on lending of -11.32%, indicating favorable lending conditions compared to treasury bill rates.

name: Social Insurance Gap
title: Low Coverage of Social Insurance in Richest Quintile
description: In 2015, only 1.87% of Zambia's richest quintile was covered by social insurance programs, suggesting a gap in social safety nets for wealthier citizens.
